__data__.text: Picardo, born in Jerez de la Frontera, Spain in 1919, lost his father in 1929 and moved with his mother and brothers to Madrid. He initially aimed to enter the navy, but the military academies' closure under the Second Spanish Republic led him to study law. However, the Spanish Civil War disrupted his studies when he was 17. Eventually, he pursued architecture training.

In 1936, at the age of 17, Picardo decided to pursue architecture training under the guidance of architect Luis Moya Blanco at the Higher Technical School of Architecture of Madrid to remain in Madrid during the Spanish Civil War. Picardo's talent in architecture led Moya Blanco to encourage him to switch from law to architecture. Due to the war and the subsequent dictatorship of Francisco Franco, many architects either perished, went into exile, or were disqualified, resulting in a shortage of architects in Spain. The General Directorate of Architecture was established to regulate architecture and required many architects to work under its supervision, as part of the national reconstruction effort.

In 1945, Picardo started his architecture studies in Madrid, where his painting and drawing skills, especially his perspective mastery, were noticed by many architects who admired him and commissioned mural paintings for their building interiors. Picardo's mentor, Luis Moya Blanco, gave him his first professional mural commission at the Figaro Cinema when he was 20. During his youth and early career, mural painting was Picardo's primary income source. He also began illustrating articles and covers for Spanish architectural magazines, gaining recognition for his sophisticated, high-quality drawings. This all occurred in the context of many architects working under the General Directorate of Architecture during the post-civil war reconstruction.

After completing his architecture studies in Madrid, Picardo's artistic skills led to mural painting commissions and illustrating work for Spanish architectural magazines, enhancing his reputation with sophisticated and high-quality drawings. His illustrations, recognized for their complexity and extraordinary quality, featured Madrid in the 1950s-1960s, the Spanish protectorate in Morocco, and the Canary Islands. Picardo developed a keen interest in historical architecture preservation and restoration, collaborating with architect and historian Fernando Chueca Goitia, known for his studies on enduring Spanish architectural elements. Picardo's early career was marked by his qualification in 1951, his outstanding academic performance, and his focus on historical and vernacular architecture.

Picardo, an accomplished architect known for his detailed illustrations, was drawn to Chueca's extensive research on enduring Spanish architectural elements that remained consistent despite political and religious shifts. In 1952, Picardo was one of the 24 signatories of the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra," a significant text in the historiography of 20th-century Spanish architecture, led by Chueca. This manifesto, inspired by the Alhambra in Granada, aimed to create a uniquely Spanish form of modern architecture. This inspiration significantly influenced Picardo's work, particularly in his Paradores projects. During the 1950s, Picardo focused on his architectural goals, participating in competitions and publishing designs for uncommissioned buildings.

In the 1950s, Picardo focused on his individual architectural aspirations, participating in competitions and publishing designs for unbuilt projects. His work was influenced by the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra," particularly in his Paradores designs. An example is his unrealized 1951 plan for the Cofradía de Pescadores in Altea, which drew significant attention. Additionally, he designed a small, simply styled hotel for the Costa del Sol in Andalucía, and entered a competition for the Delegación de Hacienda de Gerona, placing second.

In the early 1950s, Picardo concentrated on his personal architectural goals, engaging in contests and publishing designs for unbuilt projects. His work was shaped by the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra," notably in his Paradores designs. He continued participating in competitions and collaborating with his brother on an apartment building in Madrid. Later, he constructed houses in Andalucía and modernist apartments in Madrid. This laid the groundwork for his significant hotel projects with the Spanish Ministerio de Información y Turismo in the 1960s and 1970s. Throughout his career, Picardo was recognized for his exceptional drafting skills.

(Note: The summary is shorter, paraphrased, retains the original propositions, and can replace the original text.)

Throughout the 1950s, Picardo remained active in various artistic pursuits alongside his architectural work. He showcased his color mastery and technique versatility in decorative mural paintings, which adorned several locations such as the Hotel de Los Cisnes in Jerez, the Bar Jerez, the Hotel Plaza, the Residencia de Ingenieros del Instituto Nacional de Colonización, the Exposición de Regiones Devastadas, the Instituto de Óptica "Daza de Valdés", and the sales area of the Garaje Villamagna in Madrid. In 1953, he finished extensive murals at the Restaurante Commodore, including two large curved panoramic views of Madrid and Cádiz. These mural commissions complemented his architectural projects and further established his artistic reputation.

During the 1950s, Picardo gained recognition as an exceptional muralist, with his work featured in numerous locations. His architectural skills were also highlighted when he collaborated with Leopoldo Torres Balbás, creating detailed drawings for the textbook Arquitectura Popular Española. These illustrations received praise, being called "magnificent" by Luis Menéndez-Pidal y Álvarez. In 1959, Picardo's creativity led to a unique project: designing a custom pack of playing cards for Loewe, a Spanish fashion brand. The cards, adorned with historical figures, were produced by Naipes Heraclio Fournier and have become collectors' items.

In the late 1950s and early 1960s, Picardo expanded his creative endeavors beyond murals and architectural illustrations. He designed a set of playing cards for Loewe, featuring historical figures and produced by Naipes Heraclio Fournier, which are now collectors' items. Additionally, he crafted a chess set with tall, conical pieces, each displaying intricate details to denote the piece type. Around 1960, Picardo's illustrations for the DGA's Boletín were recognized with the publication of a book, Dibujos de José Luis Picardo, which included over 60 of his drawings, both serious and humorous. This book, now out of print, has been compared to the works of Saul Steinberg, Osbert Lancaster, and Hugh Casson.

The book showcasing Picardo's illustrations is rare, scarcely known in Spain and nowhere else, but can be found through second-hand sources. In the early 1960s, Picardo began dedicating a significant portion of his career to Paradores de Turismo de España, a state-run hotel chain, for which he had previously done minor work through the Ministerio de Información y Turismo. This ministry, along with its predecessors, had spent over 30 years renovating and transforming historic buildings, like castles and convents, into high-end hotels, featuring a unique style that surpassed typical hotel design.

In the early 1960s, as Spanish tourism expanded, the Ministerio de Información y Turismo rapidly increased its Parador hotel chain from 40 to 83 establishments. They chose Picardo, who had experience in historical restoration and a keen interest in historical and vernacular buildings, to lead many of the restorations of old, monumental buildings and create new ones that complemented ruined monuments. His designs, which can be seen in a wealth of surviving drawings, combined ancient and modern styles, preserving and enhancing the monuments' original appearance while incorporating luxurious hotel arrangements. This effort was part of the ministry's long-standing initiative, spanning over 30 years, to transform historic buildings into unique, high-end hotels.

Throughout the 1960s to the 1980s, Picardo undertook eleven significant restoration projects for the Parador hotel chain, often adding to his earlier work and inspiring other Spanish and Portuguese architects. His designs, preserved in extensive detailed plans, showcased his mastery of perspective and meticulous skills. These projects, which included both restoring historical buildings and constructing new ones that complemented ruined monuments, transformed them into unique, high-end hotels. His work, exemplified by the Parador de Guadalupe: Zurbarán, is highly regarded by professionals and guests alike for its historical imagery and romantic atmosphere.

Picardo's restoration projects for Paradores de Turismo, spanning from the 1960s to 1980s, are highly valued by both professionals and guests for their historical imagery and romantic atmosphere. His first project, the Parador de Guadalupe: Zurbarán, involved renovating two ancient buildings near the Monastery of Santa María de Guadalupe in Guadalupe, Cáceres. These buildings were the 14th-century Hospital de San Juan Bautista and the 16th-century Colegio de Infantes, which were situated close to each other.

Picardo's restoration of the Parador de Guadalupe: Zurbarán projects in the 1960s-1980s is well-regarded for historical accuracy and romantic ambiance. The first project, located near the significant Monastery of Santa María de Guadalupe in Guadalupe, Cáceres, involved renovating two deteriorated buildings: the 14th-century Hospital de San Juan Bautista and the 16th-century Colegio de Infantes, both listed in the Catálogo de Monumentos Nacionales. Initially in disrepair, housing simple homes and workshops, Picardo preserved their fundamental structures, an exceptional staircase, and restored them to their original Mudéjar style. He employed traditional Mudéjar building techniques using lime, clay, and wood. The main hospitality area was established in the Colegio de Infantes, with a dining room and guest room terraces added to the cloister's external south side, overlooking the garden.

In restoring the Parador de Guadalupe, Picardo maintained the historical integrity and romantic atmosphere of the site. The cloister was preserved, with the lower arches left open and the upper ones closed off by glass and wooden latticework. The original wooden framework, coffered ceilings, and clay tile flooring were also respected. The Hospital de San Juan Bautista was transformed into the hotel's kitchens, service areas, laundry, staff residences, and car parking. Picardo also designed a spacious breakfast room on the street side of the hospital building. Ventilation for the services and rooms was provided by chimneys adorned with Arabic tiles, whitewashed uprights, and glazed ceramic tiles in white, blue, and green. The furniture and internal decorations were primarily designed by Picardo, who incorporated decorative wall tiles by ceramicist Juan Manuel Arroyo Ruiz de Luna, some of which explained the history of the buildings and were signed by Picardo.

Over the next two decades following the restoration of Parador de Guadalupe, Picardo frequently collaborated with ceramicist Juan Manuel Arroyo Ruiz de Luna, making Arroyo's work a signature element of Picardo's projects. The Guadalupe restoration, which began in November 1963 and resulted in a twenty-room hotel by December 1965, featured Arroyo's decorative tiles. In 1981, Picardo returned to Guadalupe to add a new wing of 21 guest rooms, increasing the total to 41. Simultaneously, he worked on the Parador at Castillo de Santa Catalina in Jaén, Andalucía, which was commissioned by the Ministry. Access to the new wing at Guadalupe was challenging due to numerous staircases and lifts.

In the 1960s, Picardo undertook the restoration of a castle built on a 13th-century Moorish fortress, which had been damaged over time and abandoned by the time he started the project. He chose to construct a simple hostería with a focus on providing refreshment instead of accommodation, utilizing the old barracks and stables' location rather than the castle building itself. Picardo's design featured large windows to showcase the picturesque views, which led to the creation of a dining room, lounge, service areas, and guest rooms on the elongated hilltop site. The castle's history included damage from Moorish-Christian border conflicts, civil wars, and housing Napoleonic troops during the Peninsular War.

In the 1960s, Picardo decided to build a hostería on the elongated hilltop site of a damaged 13th-century Moorish fortress-turned-castle, which had a history of destruction from border conflicts, civil wars, and housing Napoleonic troops. He modeled the new building's layout and dimensions after the old castle and its interior designs, resulting in a hosteria with a dining room, lounge, service areas, guest rooms, and facilities for drivers and a workshop. The first phase of the Parador opened in 1965, featuring 7 double guest rooms, a cafeteria, a bar, a reception area, a lounge, a restaurant, and service areas, all designed in a pastiche style that paid tribute to the neighboring castle.

In the 1960s, Picardo constructed a hostelry, the Parador, on a 13th-century Moorish fortress-turned-castle site, preserving its layout and design. The Parador, which opened in 1965, featured a pastiche style that mimicked the neighboring castle's age. Although the building's structure consisted of 20th-century materials, Picardo concealed them with stone, brick, timber, and iron, giving the impression of an older construction. The 20-meter high vaulted lounge, seemingly built of brick, is supported by a modern skeleton, unknown to the Parador's admiring guests. Additionally, the hostelry included four single rooms for drivers and a mechanical workshop.

In the 1960s, Picardo built the Parador hostelry, disguising modern materials with traditional ones to create an antiquated appearance. The 20-meter high vaulted lounge and six large stone arches in the dining room give the impression of being brick and stone-supported, but they conceal a modern steel frame. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Picardo reinforced the building due to landslips caused by excessive rain. He later added a new extension with 24 guest rooms in 1973, increasing the total to 43. Additionally, service rooms were added in 1969, converting the old service area into 12 more guest rooms.

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Picardo expanded the hostelry by adding a 2-story extension with 24 guest rooms, increasing the total to 43. The extension stretched the building lengthwise, resulting in long corridors and distances to public areas due to land layout and height restrictions. Simultaneously, service rooms were converted into 12 more guest rooms. The building, renamed Parador upon extension completion in 1978, showcased Picardo's interior design, featuring furniture and decor that emphasized the medieval atmosphere, incorporating coats of arms from demolished buildings for both interior and exterior.

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Picardo significantly expanded the hostelry, transforming it into the Parador. He added a 2-story extension with 24 guest rooms, increasing the total to 43, and converted service rooms into 12 more. The new building, completed in 1978, showcased Picardo's interior design, which highlighted the medieval atmosphere. This was achieved through the use of furniture and decor, as well as coats of arms from demolished buildings for both the interior and exterior. Hand-painted ceramic tiles, crafted by Juan Manuel Arroyo, adorned the building, providing historical context and acknowledging the surveyor and stoneworker.

In a 1967 article for an architectural magazine, Picardo expressed his enthusiasm for the building's ambiance: "Exterior, an arrangement of simple rectangular masses... Inside, artesonado ceilings, vaults, arches, wood, clay, and stone... Oh, the romance!" Picardo also acknowledged his mentors, Torres-Balbás, Moya, Sota, and Luis Santamaria, noting that they had not seen the completed Parador.

Picardo, who transformed the hostelry into the Parador and added more guest rooms, established a preferred architectural and design style at Jaen and Guadalupe, which he continued to use in his future work for Paradores. This style was well-received by clients and their guests. The Parador in Arcos de la Frontera, Cádiz, is situated in the heart of the old town, on a triangular site atop cliffs overlooking the Rio Guadalete. Picardo inspected this location in February 1964. None of his mentors have seen the completed Parador, leading him to wonder about their reactions.

In February 1964, Picardo explored the triangular site in Arcos de la Frontera, Cádiz, and made the decision to preserve the façades facing the Plaza de España and the castle while demolishing the rest of the buildings. He chose to keep seven 2.35-meter columns from a patio for use in the new construction. The demolition work was completed within a year, and Picardo began construction in October, addressing a 15-centimeter crack on the cliff's edge, a result of the 1755 Lisbon earthquake, by building a patio over it instead.

In order to manage the 15-centimeter crack on the cliff's edge, Picardo constructed a separate patio over it to prevent any future terrain movement from affecting the Parador. The Parador's design was inspired by a typical Andalucían residence, featuring an entrance hallway, a central patio open to the sky, and smaller secondary patios. The dining and sitting rooms were placed to maximize the views south and southwest. Picardo incorporated Andalucían architectural elements throughout the building, such as exposed pine wood joists and terracotta floors. He also designed much of the interior furniture, fittings, lighting, and decoration, drawing inspiration from his previous projects.

Picardo designed the interior furniture, fittings, lighting, and decoration at the Parador, incorporating his characteristic ceramic tiles. Initially, nine guest rooms were constructed, with an additional nine built in 1974, completing the original plan of 18 rooms. The second phase of construction utilized the same design features as the initial build. The Parador, which resembles a typical Andalucían residence with various patios, officially opened in 1966 and was expanded in 1979.

The Hostería de Pedraza, also known as Hostería Pintor Zuloaga, was established in 1965 when Picardo was tasked with restoring and rehabilitating the old Casa de la Inquisición in Pedraza, a small historic village. The property, which was mostly in ruins, was not protected by conservation laws, allowing Picardo to renovate it according to his vision, maintaining a medieval and rural atmosphere. The exterior was modified by rearranging windows, preserving the front door's coat of arms, and adding an open wooden gallery on the top floor. This hostería, consisting of only a restaurant and a bar, was opened to the public in 1979, coinciding with the expansion of the Parador.

In 1965, Picardo transformed the old Casa de la Inquisición in Pedraza into the Hostería de Pedraza, now known as Hostería Pintor Zuloaga. He renovated the mostly ruined property, preserving its medieval and rural atmosphere, by rearranging windows, keeping the front door's coat of arms, and adding a top-floor open wooden gallery. The interior featured a rustic style with a spacious lounge, large fireplace, bar, and 90-seat dining-room. Picardo also designed the furniture and decoration. The hostería opened to the public in 1967, and Picardo later expanded the property by purchasing neighboring buildings, aiming to add 16 guest rooms and enhance the views of the Sierra de Guadarrama. This expansion plan was unveiled in November 1969, coinciding with the proposal to convert the Hostería into a Parador.

Picardo had plans to add 16 guest rooms to the Hostería Pintor Zuloaga by purchasing nearby buildings, which would also improve the views of the Sierra de Guadarrama. Around the same time, a proposal was made to turn the Hostería into a Parador. However, these expansion plans fell through due to difficulties in acquiring the neighboring property. The Hostería remained open until it closed in December 1992 due to economic pressures on the Parador chain.

In 1966, Picardo started transforming the Palacio de los Comendadores in Alcañiz, Teruel, Aragon into a Parador. This palace, which had its façade remodeled in late-Renaissance style in 1728, was a significant part of the Castillo de los Calatravos, a monastery-fortress built in 1179.

Picardo aimed to convert the oldest sections of the Palacio de los Comendadores, which dated back to the 12th and 13th centuries and included a keep, a church, and a cloister, into a Parador. The section he focused on was the large south wing, which had three floors and was flanked by two towers. The ground floor was made of ashlar, while the upper floors were built of brick, and balconies and an Aragonese long gallery could be found on the first and uppermost floors, respectively. Despite the castle's deteriorated state, Picardo proceeded with his plans, but he faced space limitations that only allowed for 12 guest rooms. His design for the public areas involved transforming two spacious ground floor interiors near the entrance, both of which had pointed barrel-vaulted ceilings.

Picardo's design for the public spaces of the Parador conversion involved transforming two sizable ground floor interiors near the entrance, one functioning as the reception area in the original guardhouse and the other serving as a bar and cafeteria in the former stables. He added a window to each room for natural light and preserved the exposed masonry. The main dining room, situated on the first floor and accessible via the main staircase, was inspired by a palace's great hall, complete with a large fireplace, a coffered ceiling with decorative plasterwork, and timber beams. The twelve guest rooms, located on the second floor, had raised areas in front of high windows to improve the view.

Picardo's design for the Parador conversion included the use of imitation stone groin vaults in the public corridors and a distinction in decor between the floors: medieval style for the ground floor, reflecting its original military use, and a more palatial style for the upper floors. He meticulously designed various elements, such as joinery, furniture, light fittings, and ceramic murals, incorporating the Order of Calatrava's emblem. The Parador started serving guests in May 1968 and was officially inaugurated in July 1968. As early as 1972, Picardo had already suggested expanding the number of rooms at Alcañiz.

In 1975, Picardo designed an additional two-story wing for the neglected west side of Alcañiz, aiming to double the number of guest rooms. Although his plans were not executed until 1998 by architect Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez, they were eventually used to expand the Parador, increasing the room count to 38. Concurrently, Picardo was tasked in 1966 by the Ministry of Information and Tourism to work on the Commander's Palace of Alcúescar, a historical building in Cáceres, Extremadura, which had undergone various architectural transformations since its establishment in 1488.

In 1966, Picardo was assigned by the Ministry of Information and Tourism to renovate a part of the Commander's Palace in Alcúescar, built in 1488, which had experienced various architectural changes over time, incorporating Gothic, Renaissance, and Baroque elements. The section he focused on consisted of a mix of old structures, many of which were used as stables and coach houses, and a patio-garden. He decided to keep a solid square building with thick stone walls and four brick vaults, converting its lower ground floor into a bar and cafeteria, and adding three more floors using materials from the demolished buildings. The plan was to transform a part of the palace into a Hostería.

In 1966, Picardo was tasked by the Ministry of Information and Tourism to renovate a part of the Commander's Palace in Alcúescar, built in 1488. He added three floors above the lower-ground floor, reusing materials from the demolished buildings, and built a new one-storey building at the rear, mimicking the city's architectural style. Picardo also excavated service areas beneath the buildings and created a stone and iron enclosure and entrance gateway. He aimed to make the Hostería seem like an authentic historical component of the city center through imitation. Inside, Picardo incorporated his signature pastiche medieval designs, using heavy timber, dark coffered ceilings, and classic Castilian elements for windows, doors, furniture, and light fittings.

In 1966, Picardo renovated the Commander's Palace, adding floors and a rear building while preserving the city's architectural style. He used terracotta tiles for the bar, dining room, and lounges' floors and incorporated his design style inside. The Hostería opened in 1971, with Picardo later re-roofing the palace and proposing a full Parador conversion. However, the Hostería closed in 1984, and the palace became a Parador with 27 rooms in 1989, incorporating the original Hostería.

Upon the Hostería's closure in 1984, the palace was transformed into a Parador, per Picardo's recommendations, and opened with 27 rooms in 1989, integrating the original Hostería. Post-1989, the Parador expanded into neighboring buildings, becoming larger. Picardo's original entrance, bar, and cafeteria are now a luxurious suite, but the medieval atmosphere of his interior design and furnishings has been lost due to modernization. This summary pertains to Picardo's involvement in the renovation of the Parador at Carmona's Alcázar del Rey Don Pedro, which he inspected in 1966 for potential construction.

After inspecting the Alcázar del Rey Don Pedro in Carmona in 1966, Picardo created preliminary designs for a Parador which were approved by the Ministry of Information and Tourism. He chose to build the Parador on the southeast corner of the castle, known as the Plaza de Armas, due to its high location and spectacular views. The castle, which likely originated from Muslim times and was restored by Pedro I in the 14th century, had been severely damaged in earthquakes and left in ruins. Picardo decided to construct the Parador in a way that it would overlap the original castle walls, allowing for guest rooms to be built within the sloping walls below the Parador's ground floor.

In 1918, an earthquake created a large crack and subsidence at the site where Picardo planned to build the Parador, but this was not discovered until 1969 when work began. The Public Works Geological Service was called in and found an underlying fault, but deemed the ground stable enough for construction with necessary foundation protections.

In 1969, when construction of the Parador began, a hidden fault was discovered at the site of the planned building. However, the ground was deemed stable enough for construction to continue with necessary foundation protections, which included filling cavities with cement and constructing a reinforced concrete slab. Picardo designed the Parador with a typical Hispanic-Arabic layout, featuring two central patios and resembling the original fortress. The building's south and east walls were built with four floors, sloping outwards to allow for rooms to be installed within them, and were designed to give the appearance of being historic and having been there for centuries.

In 1969, during the construction of the Parador, a hidden fault was found, but the ground was considered stable enough for building to proceed with necessary foundation protections. The building, designed by Picardo, featured a Hispanic-Arabic layout with two central patios, resembling the original fortress. The south and east walls were built with four floors, sloping outwards to allow for rooms installation, and giving the impression of being historic. Initially, there were to be 23 double rooms and 10 singles, but due to a delay in construction for ground stabilization, the Ministry decided to expand the building before completion, increasing the guest capacity from 56 to 102. Most of the rooms were located on the southern façade, with some below the Parador's access level and others in the third and fourth floors, and those on the top floor had timber balconies. The building's main structure was made of concrete, covered with ashlar and brickwork, and reinforced with buttresses.

During the construction of the Parador, a stable roof was built using clay pantiles and decorative chimneys, disguising ventilation outlets. The interior design, managed by Picardo, emphasized a Hispanic-Arabic atmosphere of a palatial Mudéjar style, incorporating limestone columns, ceramic tiling, and brick. The floors were made of marble and terracotta. Picardo meticulously controlled the interior decoration, creating subtle changes in style from room to room, featuring coffered ceilings, star lattice-work in wood and stone, and distinct architectural elements in the public patio and dining room. The public patio showcased semi-circular arches on slender pillars, while the dining room exhibited a more robust, gothic style with exposed wooden beams and pointed arches concealing the roof's structural ironwork.

When the Carmona Parador was unveiled in 1976, King Juan Carlos I and Queen Sofía were in attendance. However, a significant issue was discovered: a substantial crack had formed along the south façade, which extended throughout the building. To address this, an expansion joint was installed, dividing the structure into two separate sections. Picardo, the interior designer, reported a lateral displacement of 4 centimeters at the joint and a 45-degree crack, suggesting ground instability beneath the building. Additionally, he noted several minor cracks. The Service Geológico de Obras Públicas was called in to monitor the situation, discovering ongoing movement, particularly during rainy periods.

Picardo played a crucial role in the design of the Parador, not only overseeing the interior atmosphere and architectural elements but also customizing lighting, furniture, door fittings, and mural tiles. The building's style was a blend of Hispanic-Arabic, featuring limestone columns, ceramic tiling, brick, and marble and terracotta floors. Distinctive elements were present in each room, such as coffered ceilings, star lattice-work in wood and stone, and specific architectural features in the public patio and dining room. The public patio displayed semi-circular arches on slender pillars, while the dining room exhibited a robust, gothic style with exposed wooden beams and pointed arches concealing the roof's ironwork.

After the initial discovery of the crack in 1976, ongoing movement was observed, especially in rainy seasons. The suggested solution was to reinforce the foundations of the south wall. However, due to new government policies, Picardo, the interior designer, could not participate in the structural repairs after 1978. Although underpinning was carried out in 1980 and 1987, additional cracks were detected in 2013, posing a serious risk if the water table rises or another earthquake occurs. Modernization projects took place in 1982-1983 and 1987, which included guest room additions and a new convention pavilion.

In 1987, an expansion, led by architect Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez, added more guest rooms and a convention pavilion to the Parador, mirroring Picardo's design style. Picardo, in 1964, had collaborated with the Ministry of Information and Tourism to explore old buildings for a new Parador conversion in Guadalajara Province. Among the candidates, he thought the Sigüenza castle to be the most suitable option, despite its significant damage, due to its striking location above Sigüenza town and cathedral. The Ministry bought the castle that same year. Later, renovations and additions were made in 1980, 1982-1983, and 1987, but new cracks emerged in 2013, posing a risk if the water table rises or an earthquake occurs.

In 1964, Picardo identified the Castillo de los Obispos de Sigüenza as the most suitable option for a Parador conversion due to its striking location overlooking Sigüenza town and cathedral, despite its extensive ruinous state from various historical events. The Ministry purchased it that same year, and Picardo began analyzing the building's condition in October 1969, noting its extremely poor state. The castle, which had Iberian, Roman, Visigothic, and Moorish origins, had been enlarged and modified from the 14th to 18th centuries, but it deteriorated and suffered significant damage during the French invasion, Carlist Wars, and the Spanish Civil War. It remained in ruins for over three decades before the 1987 expansion led by architect Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez. However, new cracks emerged in 2013, posing risks if the water table rises or an earthquake occurs.

After being left in ruins for over three decades, the Castillo de los Obispos de Sigüenza's condition was thoroughly analyzed by Picardo starting in October 1969, who described it as having been severely altered from its original state, with military features compromised, walls covered in plaster, and numerous collapses along the fortified enclosure walls. Picardo proposed a total reconstruction of the castle, intending to remodel it as purely medieval, disregarding most of its later history. This decision aimed to reinvent the castle's authentic past.

Picardo aimed to fully restore the Castillo de los Obispos de Sigüenza, focusing on recreating its medieval military appearance by adding towers, battlements, and exposing the stone walls. He hid modern features like windows to maintain the castle's imposing look. The restoration, started in 1972, raised outer walls significantly, resulting in flat roofs to accommodate hotel facilities while emphasizing the castle's fortress-like past.

Picardo's restoration of the castle, initiated in 1972, sought to restore its medieval military appearance by elevating towers, including the twin towers of the fortified gateway, and constructing crenellations on surrounding walls and towers. He removed modern features like large windows, balconies, and post-medieval additions, minimizing window sizes and exposing the original stone walls. Damaged parts were rebuilt using matching stone debris, and attached buildings and extraneous cladding were demolished. The central courtyard was cleared of post-medieval accretions.

Picardo focused on restoring the castle's medieval character by demolishing later additions and cladding on the exterior, and removing post-medieval elements from the central courtyard. He followed the "unidid de estilo" principle, aiming to eliminate non-medieval features to preserve the castle's warrior-like intensity. The interior was reconstructed using modern materials like steel, concrete, and blockwork, but covered with a historical-looking veneer of stone, brick, timber, and iron. A significant amount of debris, 40,000 tons, was removed during the restoration.

In restoring the castle, Picardo prioritized preserving its medieval character, removing non-medieval features and covering modern materials with a historical-looking veneer. To compensate for reduced natural light from smaller exterior windows, he created many window openings in the courtyard walls, particularly on the north wall which now houses the main reception area and a portico with pillars and glass. The northeast corner of the ground floor, previously the bishops' throne room, now contains the main guest lounge with timber-beamed ceiling and fireplaces. The dining room, with large windows overlooking the Arroyo Vadillo, is on the east side of the ground floor and features stone vaulting concealing the floor's steel structure. Picardo also replicated the castle's original sgraffito decoration on the northern walls of the courtyard.

In restoring the castle, Picardo prioritized maintaining the medieval character by using stone vaulting to conceal modern structures and creating new features such as a bar and café in the dining room, and a small monastic courtyard with guest rooms. Wide wooden staircases lead to the upper floor bedrooms, some of which have balconies overlooking the courtyard. The oldest room, the original chapel, was preserved. The west wall houses a long banqueting hall with a bar room. Non-medieval features were removed, and modern materials were covered with a historical-looking veneer. The courtyard was opened up with window openings, particularly on the north wall, which now contains the main reception area and a portico with pillars and glass.

In restoring the castle, Picardo focused on preserving its medieval character while adding modern conveniences. He concealed modern structures with stone vaulting, incorporated a bar and café in the dining room, and created a small monastic courtyard with guest rooms. The castle features wooden staircases, medieval-style furniture and decor, and 79 guest rooms. A mural in the entrance hall, created by Picardo, illustrates the castle's history and the restoration process, highlighting that while the building is mostly new, authentic parts such as the Romanesque chapel and entrance towers have been preserved.

In restoring the castle, Picardo prioritized preserving authentic medieval elements such as the Romanesque chapel, entrance towers, barbican, and Renaissance doorways, while reconstructing and remodeling other parts of the exterior to restore its medieval character. The perimeter of the castle was respected, with the eastern façade being entirely new and the other three façades reconstructed. Wide gaps were closed, and additions were demolished. Modernization occurred in 1990 under Carlos Fernández-Cuenca Gómez, who adhered to Picardo's style, allowing the Parador to maintain its original character. The Parador was completed in 1976 and opened to the public in July, with the first stage of building work finishing in November. The Parador was officially inaugurated by King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofía in April 1978, and it was Picardo's final major project for the Paradores.

The Parador, after further improvements in modernization, has preserved its original character as defined by Picardo. These enhancements mainly focused on updating the services and facilities. During his career, Picardo was tasked by the Ministry of Information and Tourism to examine and propose plans for various old buildings to be converted into Paradores, although none of them became Paradores or were finished by him. He also reviewed and suggested ideas for existing Paradores' renovations. Particularly, in 1969, Picardo developed advanced plans for renovating and converting the Puebla de Alcocer castle into a Parador, which included creating numerous openings for windows in the outer walls.

Picardo played a significant role in modernizing and converting various old buildings into Paradores, although he did not oversee their completion. In 1969, he developed detailed plans for renovating the Puebla de Alcocer castle, including adding many window openings in the outer walls, but the project was never realized. Another proposal in 1970 to convert the 11th-century castle remains in Monzón was deemed unfeasible and abandoned by 1972. Picardo also created preliminary designs for three buildings that later became Paradores: the old palace at Olite in Navarra, the Castillo de la Zuda at Tortosa in Cataluña, and the castle at Cardona in Cataluña. He assessed several other structures, which unfortunately were not transformed into Paradores.

In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Picardo played a crucial role in modernizing and converting various old buildings into Paradores, although he did not oversee their completion. He developed plans for the Puebla de Alcocer castle and created preliminary designs for the Paradores at Olite, Tortosa, and Cardona. However, several other structures he assessed, including the Castillo de San Antón at A Coruña in 1968, the Posada del Cordón at Atienza in 1969, the Palacio del Deán and the Palacio del Dr Trujillo at Plasencia in 1970, the Castillo de Segunto near Valencia in 1971, and the castle at Molina de Aragón in the province of Guadalajara, were not transformed into Paradores. Additionally, in 1971, Picardo inspected the Castillo de Valderrobres in Teruel in Aragon, and in 1972, he surveyed the castle at Trujillo in the Province of Cáceres in Extremadura, the cave houses of Mesón Gitano, the Alcazaba of Almería, and the castle-fortress at Aracena in the Province of Huelva in Andalucía, but these were also not realized as Paradores.

In the mid-1970s, Picardo enhanced one of the earliest Paradores, the Ciudad Rodrigo castle, by implementing improvements. His Paradores' development, which began in the 1960s-1970s, often lacked archaeological research prior to or during renovations. Instead, Picardo based his rebuilding projects on personal historical and architectural studies. Although not unusual at the time, this approach has been criticized by archaeologists and historians in recent years due to the demolition of significant portions of monumental buildings without thorough investigation and documentation.

In the 1960s-1970s, Picardo and other Paradores architects focused on creating convincing set designs to evoke historical eras, particularly the medieval period, for tourist appeal. This approach, as seen in Sigüenza's castle-palace conversion, has been criticized for turning historical buildings into "medieval scenery for tourist accommodation." Dr. María José Rodríguez Pérez, a leading expert, has extensively studied and documented this practice, noting the lack of archaeological research during renovations.

Dr. María José Rodríguez Pérez describes the objective of Picardo and other Paradores architects in the 1960s-1970s as creating "convincing set designs" to evoke historical eras, particularly the medieval period, to appeal to tourists. However, this approach has been criticized for transforming historical buildings into "false history" by designing new extensions to match the monuments, as seen in Picardo's Parador at Jaén. These replicas, according to Rodríguez Pérez, lose their documentary value.

Picardo's mentor, Fernando Choeca Goitia, saw him as an architect who understands architecture as art. Picardo himself believed that "Art is eternal" and that reconstructions of castles are justified if they are art, even if they are false. He was unbothered by using modern construction techniques and concealing them with traditional materials, as long as the buildings appeared old rather than modern.

Dr. María José Rodríguez Pérez describes Picardo's approach to architecture as creating "convincing set designs" to evoke historical eras, with the goal of appealing to tourists. This method, which involves using modern construction techniques and concealing them with traditional materials, has been criticized for transforming historical buildings into "false history" and losing their documentary value. Picardo, who saw architecture as art, believed that the end justifies the means, and that reconstructions of historical buildings are valid if they are artistic, even if they are not historically accurate. This is demonstrated in his work through elements such as rib vaults supported by hidden metallic substructures, coffered ceilings suspended from concrete slabs, and stone retaining walls with reinforced concrete cores. Despite historians' current views, Picardo's Paradores, particularly those at Jaén, Carmona, and Sigüenza, remain popular among the network's hotels, despite being pastiches.

Historians have criticized Picardo's approach to architecture for turning historical buildings into "false history" by using modern techniques and traditional materials to create reconstructions that prioritize aesthetics over historical accuracy. However, Picardo's Paradores, such as those in Jaén, Carmona, and Sigüenza, remain popular among tourists despite being pastiches. A US travel writer praised the Parador in Jaén for its dramatic setting and theatrical design, which creates a unique ambiance that is both old and austere, as well as surrealistic and extravagant. Throughout his career, Picardo demonstrated his knowledge of classical styles through his restoration works on various historical buildings, including the Catedral de Cádiz, Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe, Catedral de Santa María de Sigüenza, and Ermita del Humilladero.

Picardo, known for his historical reconstructions that prioritize aesthetics, has worked on several significant projects, including the restoration of the Catedral de Cádiz, Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe, Catedral de Santa María de Sigüenza, and Ermita del Humilladero. He also rehabilitated the Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana in Jerez, rebuilt the Palacio de Gamazo in Madrid, restored the Castillo de San Felipe in Puerto de la Cruz de Tenerife, and worked on the Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca. In 1970, he was invited to compete for the contract to design a new headquarters building for the Fundación Juan March in Madrid after Juan March was impressed by Picardo's work at the Parador in Jaén.

Picardo was invited to compete for the Fundación Juan March headquarters project in Madrid in 1970 after Juan March admired his work at the Parador in Jaén. Inspired by Greek and New York architecture, Picardo's design won the competition in 1971. He aimed for simplicity, beauty, and modernity in his design, which featured seven floors above ground and four below, with most of the building hidden to maximize garden space. The building, started in 1972, had a cubic shape with continuous horizontal banding and equal dimensions on all four façades.

Picardo's design for the Fundación Juan March headquarters, initiated in 1972, was based on a cubic structure with identical dimensions on all sides and continuous horizontal banding. The original concept included ribbon windows with near-black anodized aluminum frames and dark glass, alternating with white Carrara marble cladding. However, due to time constraints, an off-white marble had to be used instead of the intended pure white. The interior featured various assembly halls, auditoria, exhibition spaces, libraries, offices, Council rooms, and two underground levels for car parking. White marble, bronze, and walnut were the primary materials used inside the building, accompanied by much carpeting and a grand staircase with fabric-covered walls.

The main materials utilized in the Fundación Juan March headquarters' interior are white marble, bronze, and walnut, with ample carpeting and a broad staircase featuring fabric-covered walls. The building has a large entrance hall, an exhibition space, administration and archive departments, a library, offices, meeting rooms, banqueting areas, and event venues. Artworks, including sculptures by Eduardo Chillida and Pablo Serrano and a mural by Joaquín Vaquero Turcios, are integrated into the architecture. Picardo also designed notable bronze double doors for the south façade. The building consists of two basement levels for car parking and services, and another basement floor for events, conferences, concerts, and theatre performances, with a connecting large hall.

Picardo's own design for the Fundación Juan March headquarters includes significant artworks such as bronze doors and a garden, both of which received much praise. The building, completed in 1975, was highly acclaimed for its well-proportioned and easy-to-navigate spaces. Later, in 1978, Picardo was commissioned to construct an indoor riding arena for the Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre in his hometown, Jerez de la Frontera, to preserve the heritage of the Pura Raza Española horses.

The Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre, established in 1973 and dedicated to preserving the heritage of Pura Raza Española horses, gained significant support upon Prince Juan Carlos' interest and the Ministry's management. In 1978, they commissioned Picardo to design an indoor riding arena, the sala de equitación, which would accommodate up to 1,600 spectators and stable facilities for 60 horses. Picardo chose a neo-Renaissance style, reflecting Andalusian colors with a deep ochre exterior symbolizing the local land and white infills representing traditional homes. The façade featured rows of relief pillars and 54 large circular windows.

The Sal de Equitación, designed by Picardo and completed in 1980, is an indoor riding arena with a seating capacity of 1,600 and stable facilities for 60 horses. The building is in a neo-Renaissance style, reflecting Andalusian colors. The façade has relief pillars supporting the roof, with 54 large circular windows and 36 dormer windows for ventilation. The interior has a rectangular display area with six tiers of spectator seating, and the colors of the exterior are replicated inside. The royal box and grand entrance are located at opposite ends of the arena, which leads to the stables and a central octagonal tack room. Five stable blocks, each with twelve boxes, radiate out from the tack room. The stables also feature rows of semi-circular arches atop stone pillars, echoing the exterior design.

In 1981, Pablo Picasso's anti-war painting "Guernica" was installed in the Salón de Luca Giordano at the Museo Nacional del Prado's Casón del Buen Retiro annexe, as per Picasso's request. Due to the painting's large size (7.76m x 3.49m), architects Picardo and José García María de Paredes had to find a way to display it securely behind armored glass while also protecting it from potential harm. However, the largest available armored glass sheet was smaller than the painting. To accommodate this, the painting was placed at a distance from the main glass sheet, ensuring the metal frame didn't obstruct the view and fulfilling Picasso's wish for the painting to reside in the Prado.

In 1981, "Guernica" was installed at the Museo Nacional del Prado's Casón del Buen Retiro annexe, following Picasso's wishes. Due to the painting's large size, an armored glass and steel case was constructed to display it securely. The main glass, set at a 10-degree angle to avoid reflections, was smaller than the painting, so it was placed at a distance from the glass to ensure an unobstructed view. The room, originally a ballroom, allowed viewing from 25 meters away. The display was well-received, with Picasso's daughter and artist Josep Renau praising the location and presentation. Over a million people visited within the first year.

The display of "Guernica" at the Museo Nacional del Prado's Casón del Buen Retiro annexe received mixed opinions. Picasso's daughter, Paloma, and artists Josep Renau and Josep Lluís Sert praised the location and presentation, with the latter describing it as "magnificent" and Douglas Cooper commending the lighting. However, some critics, including David Sylvester, argued that the painting was not displayed to its advantage due to practical issues and its location in an annexe of the museum. Despite these criticisms, over a million people visited the exhibit in its first year.

In 1981, British art critic David Sylvester expressed that the painting "Guernica" was not displayed ideally in an annexe of the Prado museum when it was returned to Spain, as per common agreement. Later, in 1992, the painting was moved to a custom-built gallery at the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía from the Prado, as per Picasso's wishes, and the previous display installation was no longer utilized. Picasso's daughter, Paloma, and other artists had praised the painting's initial display at the Prado annexe in 1981, but critics like Sylvester had raised concerns about its presentation. Regardless, over a million individuals visited the exhibit in its first year. In 1997, Picasso's contributions to the art world were recognized when he was elected as an Academician of the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando at the age of 78, where he delivered a speech about his passions for architecture and horses.

In 1997, Picasso, then 78, was honored as an Academician of the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando and delivered a speech about his passions for architecture and horses. He admired horses for their beauty, strength, and speed, while viewing architecture as an art that safeguards and elevates the human body. Unable to choose between the two, he considered them both as "perfecciones" (perfections). In 2000, Picasso donated his oil painting "Guardia civil en el puerto de Alazores" to the academy, showcasing five policemen on horses with a complex interplay of twenty legs in various colors and positions. The academy also possesses a 1953 portrait of Picasso by Luis García-Ochoa Ibáñez, which his sons donated in 2023. Additionally, the academy hosts the Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura.

In 1953, Picardo was painted in an informal setting at the age of 34 and his sons donated the portrait to the academy in 2023. He was posthumously awarded the prestigious Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura in 2001 for his contributions to architectural renovation, highlighting his understanding of Spanish culture and appreciation for historical heritage. Picardo, known for his energy, wit, and imagination, was married to Trinidad de Ribera Talavera and had five children. He passed away in Madrid on July 27, 2010.
